natural problem: The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.

Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\

&\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_win ^ 4 = 81 / 256"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_win ^ 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of winning four times in a row if the probability of winning one game is $\frac{3}{4}$? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If the probability of winning a game is $\frac{3}{4}$, what is the probability of winning four games in a row? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

theorem
fixes probability_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_grunters_win = 3/4"
shows  "probability_grunters_win ^ 4 = 81 / 256"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof

 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.

theorem
fixes probability_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_grunters_win = 3/4"
shows  "probability_grunters_win ^ 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof-

a_4.informal problem: If the Grunters have a probability of $\frac{3}{4}$ of winning a single game, what is the probability that they win four games in a row? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 1 = 3/4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. P (Suc n) = P n * 3/4"
shows  "P 4 = 81 / 256"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 1 = 3/4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. P (Suc n) = P n * 3/4"
shows  "P 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A sequence $P_n$ is defined recursively by $P_1 = \frac{3}{4}$ and $P_{n+1} = P_n * \frac{3}{4}$. Find the value of $P_4$. The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 3 / 4"
shows  "p powr 4 = 81 / 256"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof

 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 3 / 4"
shows  "p powr 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the fourth power of $\frac{3}{4}$? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "p_grunters_win = 3 / 4"
and h1 : "0 \<le> p_grunters_win"
and h2 : "p_grunters_win \<le> 1"
shows  "p_grunters_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "p_grunters_win = 3 / 4"
and h1 : "0 \<le> p_grunters_win"
and h2 : "p_grunters_win \<le> 1"
shows  "p_grunters_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If the probability of the Grunters winning a game is $\frac{3}{4}$, what is the probability of them winning four games in a row? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 1 = 3/4"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 2. P n = (P (n - 1)) * (3/4)"
shows  "P 4 = 81 / 256"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 1 = 3/4"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 2. P n = (P (n - 1)) * (3/4)"
shows  "P 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A sequence is defined by $P_1 = \frac{3}{4}$ and $P_n = P_{n-1} \cdot \frac{3}{4}$ for all $n \geq 2$. Find the value of $P_4$. The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_grunters_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_grunters_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grunters play the Screamers 4 times.  The Grunters are the much better team, and are $75\%$ likely to win any given game.  What is the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{81}{256}
 ### Proof
 Each of the 4 games is independent of the others, and in each game, the Grunters have probability $\frac34$ of winning.
 Therefore, to get the probability that the Grunters will win all 4 games, we multiply the probabilities that the Grunters win each individual game. This gives:  \begin{align} &P(\text{Grunters win all 4 games}) \\
 &\quad= P(\text{Grunters win Game 1}) \times \cdots \times P(\text{Grunters win Game 4}) \\ &\quad= \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{3}{4} \\ &\quad= \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{\!4} = \boxed{\frac{81}{256}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_grunters_win :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_grunters_win = 3 / 4"
shows  "probability_grunters_win powr 4 = 81 / 256"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: What is the probability that the Grunters win four times in a row, if their probability of winning a single game is $\frac{3}{4}$? The final answer is $\frac{81}{256}$.
